description: New OpenVPN platform string detected ('IV_PLAT=linux'), but no direct indicator of malicious activity.
Unusual DNS query with high-entropy and suspicious structure resembling exfiltration via DNS using crafted subdomains.
High-entropy domain name in DNS query indicative of potential C2 communication over DNS.
New IP address seen in DNS logs for a legitimate domain (motd.ubuntu.com), likely part of regular OS behavior.
Unusual service start parameters for 'grub-common' via systemd might suggest manipulation of bootloader-related services.
Unusual service stop for 'grub-common', matching the previously seen start, consistent with bootloader tampering.
Slight deviation in CPU usage from historical average; not significant enough to indicate an attack.
System message from GRUB logging successful boot; no indicators of attack present.
High-entropy referrer from obscure subdomain suggests possible phishing or watering hole attack using crafted site.
New characters in HTTP referer support previous high-entropy detection, suggesting crafted external site redirection.
Unusual new IP performing DNS query to a known external service (motd.ubuntu.com), which may indicate beaconing behavior
Unusual spike in A-record DNS queries for internal subdomains like intranet.price.fox.org, which may suggest subdomain enumeration
GET request to root path may indicate vulnerability scanning or web server probing
High-frequency DNS queries from internal IPs including SRV record for security.ubuntu.com, which could suggest service enumeration
PTR (reverse DNS) query anomaly detected, likely host enumeration via reverse lookup
Standard DNS query to motd.ubuntu.com, low count, and a normal service; anomaly likely due to volume thresholding
Query for internal-looking AAAA record (IPv6) for taylorcruz-mail with low frequency, may indicate malware using IPv6 C2 channel
TXT record lookup to clamav.net could be legitimate or an evasion method using TXT records as C2
Repeated AAAA queries for suspicious host 'taylorcruz-mail', which may signal persistence or beaconing attempts
Same timestamp as previous, corroborated by frequency anomaly in DNS query IPs, confirming beaconing suspicion
Unusually high frequency of PTR DNS queries from internal host, suggesting reverse DNS lookups to map network.
TLS negotiation failure for OpenVPN session; repeated failed connections may indicate credential brute force or misconfigured attacker probing VPN.
TLS handshake failure in OpenVPN session, reinforcing abnormal VPN access behavior.
Session state change in OpenVPN logs; attacker may be attempting to interfere with or hijack a VPN session.
Repeated TLS negotiation failure from the same IP, consistent with brute-force attempts or misconfigured malicious client.
Second handshake failure log from same session/IP, further supporting persistence of suspicious access attempts.
Yet another TLS negotiation failure suggesting continued VPN brute force or connection probing behavior.
Duplicate failure at handshake step, part of a sequence of failed VPN access attempts indicating possible intrusion attempts.
Unusual characters in WebDAV PROPFIND request; headless browser used suggests automated reconnaissance or scanning.
Headless Chrome requests to photo directory with encoded characters; likely automated probing for files or data.
Request to a referer URL containing unexpected special characters such as parentheses may indicate web crawling or enumeration.
Deprecated PHP constructor usage detected, possibly exposing vulnerabilities in public-facing Horde webmail service.
Slight increase in TXT record frequency for ClamAV domain; could indicate a probe or alternate channel usage for C2.
Repeated anomalous frequency of TXT DNS queries; may be exfiltration or C2 using DNS TXT records.
Query to suspicious high-entropy domain 'i.li.ru' could indicate algorithmically generated domains for evading detection.
High-frequency DNS A record query to domain with obfuscated and complex structure suggests DNS tunneling or exfiltration.
Multiple unusual IPs making frequent DNS queries, especially toward obfuscated domains, suggest lateral or coordinated botnet activity.
New SSH login to system using root-level UID with unknown account; might be reconnaissance or pivoting via stolen credentials.
Login via dovecot authentication backend using a new user with UID 0 might indicate misconfiguration abuse or privilege escalation.
Access to WordPress admin script with new request parameters, possible plugin enumeration or attack vector probing.
High-entropy DNS query with encoded string and suspicious file name (customers_2015.xlsx) suggests data exfiltration via DNS tunneling.
Unusual authentication with UID 0 (root) and account 'michael.davis' from Dovecot, possibly indicating lateral movement or misuse of system-level authentication.
DNS query to 'ipv4only.arpa' is common for NAT64 testing; alert due to entropy threshold slightly below threshold, not a real anomaly.
Another 'ipv4only.arpa' query with minor entropy variation; known test domain; likely benign.
Forwarded DNS request to 'ipv4only.arpa'; consistent with test or benign lookup behavior.
Repeated lookup for ipv4only.arpa from same source; low entropy not indicative of malicious behavior.
Repeated forwarded query of test domain 'ipv4only.arpa' with no signs of abuse or encoding.
Another instance of benign ipv4only.arpa query, likely triggered due to overly sensitive entropy detection.
Reverse DNS lookup for 172.17.131.81 returning internal mail server; likely benign name resolution but could be discovery activity.
Uncommon HTTP method 'REPORT' via WebDAV may indicate exfiltration or enumeration using legitimate service.
A new internal IP (192.168.131.118) initiated a DNS query to location.services.mozilla.com, which may indicate new beaconing behavior or an unrecognized device on the network.
A new sudo credential refresh was detected with root privileges. This suggests potential privilege escalation or unauthorized sudo use.
Root session opened via sudo, a new value combination. Likely part of privilege escalation or lateral movement activity.
Sudo session closed for root. This could be a continuation or termination of a suspicious privilege escalation.
Credential disposal using sudo for root account. This could indicate manipulation of authentication credentials or session clearing.
Unusual GET request with unfamiliar characters in URL to a webmail memo service; could indicate probing or parameter manipulation.
Suspicious referer URL with modified characters pointing to internal memo.php. Could be part of a parameter tampering or XSS test.
A new Dovecot auth login for user 'meghan.morris' from an IP address using PAM. Could be a brute-force attempt or compromised credentials.
Audit of an account 'meghan.morris' not seen before using /usr/lib/dovecot/auth. May indicate account enumeration or lateral movement.
POST request to a calendar listing service with an unexpected character, possibly indicating automated enumeration or probing.
New characters in POST request to web application endpoint suggest probing or fuzzing behavior on AJAX endpoint.
High entropy domain suggests possible use of automatically generated domain names, often linked to malware C2 communications.
Repeated detection of high entropy in same domain ('cdn.ampproject.org') may be due to benign CDN domain, likely duplicate of previous alert.
New internal IP address making DNS queries could indicate new or rogue system on the network.
New device querying DNS for motd.ubuntu.com indicates possible new host initialization or VM spawn.
Yet another new IP querying external domain, suggesting a potential expansion of internal network scope.
New characters in referer field to intranet page suggest first-time access or scanning of specific internal web content.
Unusual character in plugin request URI ('z' from wpdiscuz) could suggest enumeration or first-time probing of plugin assets.
Multiple new characters in referer to plugin resource point to possible automated enumeration of plugin asset tree.
Referer anomaly on font resource suggests plugin file access, potentially for fingerprinting or vulnerability detection.
POST request to /wp-admin/admin-ajax.php with new unseen character 'x', possibly indicating exploitation of vulnerable admin endpoints or file upload vector
High entropy detected in domain 'taylorcruz-mail', suggesting possible DNS tunneling or exfiltration over DNS
Unusual high frequency of AAAA DNS queries, possibly indicative of beaconing behavior over IPv6
Repeated high entropy domain queries to 'taylorcruz-mail', suggesting covert DNS-based data exchange
New combination of 'apt-daily-upgrade' systemd service start by UID 0, possibly indicating malicious use of scheduled tasks or disguised service
Service stop log entry for 'apt-daily-upgrade' by root, same as suspicious service start, indicates full lifecycle execution of rogue service
Query for ocsp.pki.goog – legitimate high entropy domain used for certificate status verification; falsely flagged by entropy detector
Forwarded ocsp.pki.goog to 8.8.8.8 – part of standard OCSP verification flow
Query AAAA for ocsp.pki.goog – regular IPv6 resolution of certificate verification domain
Another DNS forward for ocsp.pki.goog, duplicated detection of benign action
High entropy in DNS domain name (ocsp.pki.goog) suggests possible use of DGA for command and control
Repeated high entropy in known domain (ocsp.pki.goog), likely benign OCSP traffic, flagged due to statistical anomaly
Unusual frequency of DNS queries for 'jonesmorgan-mail' could indicate beaconing or internal enumeration
Query to 'motd.ubuntu.com' is part of normal Ubuntu system operation
Anomaly in frequency of DNS query to 'taylorcruz-mail' may suggest abnormal service communication
Repetitive and abnormal DNS query pattern to 'jonesmorgan-mail' might indicate automated communication or scanning
Query to 'current.cvd.clamav.net' is a known benign domain used by ClamAV for virus database updates
Unauthorized access attempt to mail system by user 'megan.johnson' indicates potential abuse or misconfiguration
High frequency DNS queries to 'mail.dmz.price.fox.org' from internal IP suggest C2 beaconing or lateral movement
Significant deviation in CPU usage pattern on intranet-server could indicate unauthorized CPU-intensive tasks such as cryptomining
Anomalous DNS query frequency from internal IPs suggests potential use of DNS as a covert channel for data exfiltration or command/control.
Unusual characters in HTTP request (parentheses) and direct file download path suggest attempts to exfiltrate data from Nextcloud/Owncloud service.
Another instance of a suspicious file download URL with special characters possibly indicating automated scraping or unauthorized access.
Spike in CPU usage without corresponding user/system activity may indicate hidden computational processes such as cryptojacking.
High PTR query frequency may indicate internal network reconnaissance or enumeration using reverse DNS lookups.
Repeat of the suspicious file download request with unique token and non-standard characters—potential data exfiltration.
Similar suspicious file download via cloud-access log, indicating repeated unauthorized access or testing.
Unusual frequency of DNS AAAA queries to specific domain hints at possible C2 channel or malware communication setup.
Repeat of abnormal DNS AAAA queries with the same domain suggests ongoing malicious communication.
Continued DNS query anomalies, including forwarded replies, cached lookups, and uncommon query types—possible tunneling activity.
